data.name: Old school texting
data.description:
Old school texting
==================

Remember the time, when you were able to write text messages on your old phone with the speed rivaling the speed of light? (At least it felt like it. Am I the only one here, who hates typing on touchscreen?)

Write a function `numWriter()`, that simulates writing expressions on an old phone(they used to have buttons), by typing only numbers instead of letters, and using dictionaries.

Rules of thumb:
---------------
One number goes in instead of one letter. A number can reference more letters, and every letter is referenced only by exactly one number.

The phone you will write this program for, has the following button layout:

![Button layout](http://i.stack.imgur.com/WYOQu.png)


Arguments given
---------------

- `nums` string, the sequence to decode

- `dict` array, containing the words the phone knows. You dont have to worry about upper or lowercase, each element of `dict` will be lowercased.

What to return?
---------------

If you find words in `dict`, that start with the letters you can get from `nums` (after doing your magic) return them as strings in an Array, sorted by their occurence in `dict`, and end it with the `nums`.
If you don't find any match, return the number passed in.

To shed some light, here are some examples:

```javascript
var dict1 = ['a', 'aa','dd','gg'];
var dict2 = ['pay', 'may', 'say', 'fay', 'ray', 'saying'];

numWriter('',     dict1)  // returns []
numWriter('2',    dict1)  // returns ['a', 'aa', '2']
numWriter('22',   dict1)  // returns ['aa', '22']
numWriter('3',    dict1)  // returns ['dd', '3']
numWriter('5',    dict1)  // returns ['5']
numWriter('729',  dict2)  // returns ['pay','say','ray', 'saying', '729']
numWriter('7294', dict2)  // returns ['saying', '7294']
numWriter('632',  [])     // returns ['632']
```
Have fun!
